path2_open_standards.name: PostgreSQL Standard (Managed Provider)
path2_open_standards.description: Use managed PostgreSQL (Supabase, Neon, RDS, etc.)
pros: LOW lock-in (can migrate between providers, 8-40 hours)
Zero operational burden (managed backups, updates, scaling)
PostgreSQL standard (PromQL, extensions, tools all work)
cons: Higher cost ($25-500/month depending on provider, scale)
Some provider-specific features create soft lock-in (Neon branching, Supabase auth)

when_to_use.data_model: Relational model fits (structured data, ACID transactions)
when_to_use.team_skills: Team knows SQL (PostgreSQL expertise or can learn)
when_to_use.project_timeline: Medium-to-long-term project (portability pays off over time)

path3_proprietary.name: Proprietary Database Services
pros: Unique features (MongoDB flexible schema, DynamoDB global tables)
Deep cloud integration (DynamoDB with AWS ecosystem)
cons: HIGH lock-in (query language, data model, APIs all proprietary)
Migration out is expensive (100-500 hours to rewrite)
Higher costs at scale (DynamoDB can be 10x more expensive)

when_to_use.unique_features: Specific features justify lock-in (DynamoDB global tables, Firestore real-time)
when_to_use.data_model: NoSQL data model is better fit (rare)

migration_effort_hours.note: to rewrite application for migration out

hybrid_approach.pattern: Use PostgreSQL as primary DB, add specialized DB for specific use cases
hybrid_approach.benefit: Get PostgreSQL portability for core data, use proprietary DB where it excels

justification: LOW lock-in (can switch providers in 8-40 hours)
avoid_postgresql_when: Need specific NoSQL features (DynamoDB global tables, Firestore real-time)
Data model doesn't fit relational (rare - most data is relational)
Team has zero SQL expertise and can't learn (rare)
recommendation.bottom_line: PostgreSQL is the safe, portable choice for 90% of applications. Use proprietary DB only when unique features clearly justify lock-in.
